4. .. Bf5
mainLine
moving the white squared
bishop out of the pawn chain.
White usually plays5. Ng3 but Nc5
is playable.5. .. Bg6

<
6. Nf3
threatens Ne5 and keeps up
the h4 threat as well.6. .. e6
(6. .. Nd7 is good as well)
Ne5 is fine for black as after
7. .. Nd7 8. Nxg6 hxg6 black
development is good and has a
semi open file on h. **7. h4
h6 and we are back in the main
line.
>
g.text: Ne5 is fine for black as after
development is good and has a
semi open file on h. **7. h4
h6 and we are back in the main

>-><
6. Nf3
threatens Ne5 and keeps up
the h4 threat as well.6. .. e6
(6. .. Nd7 is good as well)
Ne5 is fine for black as after
7. .. Nd7 8. Nxg6 hxg6 black
development is good and has a
semi open file on h. **7. h4
h6 and we are back in the main
line.
>

<
5. Nc5
is playable kick the night
away with 5. .. b6 6. Nb3 Nf6.
c pawn for black is somewhat
weak in this variation, can be
attacked with fincettoed
bishop, knight on e5, black
can defend with rook c8 and
queen moves.
>

<
8. h5
8. .. Bh7 9. Bd3 Bxd3 10.
Qxd3 Nf6 At this point black has
a nice equal position where he
solved the white squared
bishop problem and has good
development.
>

g.title:
<
6. h4
mainLine
6. .. 46 7. Nf3 e6
>-><
8. h5
8. .. Bh7 9. Bd3 Bxd3 10.
Qxd3 Nf6 At this point black has
a nice equal position where he
solved the white squared
bishop problem and has good
development.
>

<
9. Qh5
threat of mate on f79. ..
Qc7 10. Bc4 Nf6 11. Qe2 Bd6
>

<
8. Ne5
Looks scary as exchanging the
bishop would destroy black's
pawn structure.8. .. Bh7
>-><
9. Qh5
threat of mate on f79. ..
Qc7 10. Bc4 Nf6 11. Qe2 Bd6
>

<
9. Bd3
mainLine
black can't take pawn on d4
although there is no check
attack against the queen with
Bb5 but after Nxf7 Kxf7 the
discovered check winning the
queen is possible9. .. Bxd3 10. Qxd3
Nd7 11. f4 Bb4+ provokes12.
c3 Bd6 threat to capture
knight on e as d pawn can not
be used to recapture because
white queen would be lost.13. Qe2
Nf6 complications on the king
side if Qc7 played instead for
example, this blocks Nh5 by
white14. Nf5 if taken black
queen is lost with 15. Nxc6+14.
.. Bf8 15. Bd2 Qc7 knight on
f5 needs to retreat now either
to g3 or e316. Ne3 Bd6 17.
0-0-0 0-0
>
g.text: black can't take pawn on d4
Bb5 but after Nxf7 Kxf7 the
knight on e as d pawn can not
side if Qc7 played instead for
f5 needs to retreat now either

g.title:
<
8. Ne5
Looks scary as exchanging the
bishop would destroy black's
pawn structure.8. .. Bh7
>-><
9. Bd3
mainLine
black can't take pawn on d4
although there is no check
attack against the queen with
Bb5 but after Nxf7 Kxf7 the
discovered check winning the
queen is possible9. .. Bxd3 10. Qxd3
Nd7 11. f4 Bb4+ provokes12.
c3 Bd6 threat to capture
knight on e as d pawn can not
be used to recapture because
white queen would be lost.13. Qe2
Nf6 complications on the king
side if Qc7 played instead for
example, this blocks Nh5 by
white14. Nf5 if taken black
queen is lost with 15. Nxc6+14.
.. Bf8 15. Bd2 Qc7 knight on
f5 needs to retreat now either
to g3 or e316. Ne3 Bd6 17.
0-0-0 0-0
>

<
11. Bf4
black has Qa5 with exchanging
bishops and queens with good,
equal position, better pawn
structure after the exchanges.
>

<
8. h5
8. .. Bh7 9. Bd3 Bxd3 10.
Qxd3 Nf6 At this point black has
a nice equal position where he
solved the white squared
bishop problem and has good
development.
